message.content: This question requires knowledge about the behavior of gases at different temperatures. At extreme negative temperatures, a gaseous cloud can condense and transform into a solid. This process is known as deposition. Option (B) is incorrect because gases typically contract and become more dense at lower temperatures, rather than expanding outwardly. Option (C) is unlikely because the cloud would still exist, although in a different state. Option (D) is incorrect because liquids form at higher temperatures than solids, and extreme negative temperatures would not cause a gas to become a liquid.

This question requires some knowledge about the behavior of gases at extreme temperatures. When a gas is exposed to extreme negative temperatures, it can cause the gas to condense and turn into a solid. This phenomenon is known as deposition. Option (B) is incorrect because extreme negative temperatures would cause the gas to contract rather than expand. Option (C) is also incorrect because the gas does not disappear altogether, it simply changes state. Option (D) is incorrect because extreme negative temperatures would not cause the gas to become a liquid, but rather a solid.

This question requires basic knowledge about the behavior of gases at different temperatures. When exposed to extreme negative temperatures, a gaseous cloud can condense to a solid state. This is because the molecules in the gas slow down and come closer together, eventually forming a solid. Option (B) is incorrect because extreme negative temperatures cause molecules to contract, not expand. Option (C) is incorrect because the cloud may change its state, but it doesn't disappear altogether. Option (D) is incorrect because extreme negative temperatures cause gases to solidify, not become a liquid.

This question requires basic knowledge about the behavior of gases at different temperatures. When extreme negative temperatures are reached, the particles in a gaseous cloud lose energy and slow down, causing the gas to condense and transition into a solid state. Option (B) is incorrect because cold temperatures typically cause gases to contract and become more condensed. Option (C) is also incorrect because extreme negative temperatures do not cause a gas cloud to disappear, but rather change its state. Option (D) is incorrect because extreme negative temperatures do not cause a gas to become a liquid, but rather a solid.

This question involves knowledge about the behavior of gases at extreme temperatures. When temperatures are extremely negative, gases can condense and transform into solid form. This process is known as deposition. Option (B) is incorrect because gases typically contract and become denser at low temperatures rather than expand. Option (C) is unlikely because even at extremely low temperatures, some gas particles will likely still be present. Option (D) is incorrect because extreme negative temperatures would not cause a gas to become a liquid, but rather a solid.

This question requires knowledge about the effects of extreme negative temperatures on a gaseous cloud. When the temperature drops, the particles in the cloud slow down and lose energy. This causes the gas to condense and transition into a solid form, such as ice crystals or snowflakes. Option (B) is incorrect because extreme negative temperatures do not cause the cloud to expand outwardly. Option (C) is incorrect because the cloud does not disappear altogether, it simply changes form. Option (D) is incorrect because extreme negative temperatures do not cause the cloud to become a liquid.

This question tests understanding of the effects of extreme negative temperatures on gases. When the temperature gets extremely cold, gases can lose energy and condense into solid form. This process is known as condensation. Option (B) is incorrect because extreme negative temperatures would cause the gas to contract rather than expand outwardly. Option (C) is also incorrect because the gas does not disappear completely; it simply changes state. Option (D) is incorrect because extreme negative temperatures would not cause the gas to become a liquid, but rather a solid.

This question requires basic knowledge about the behavior of gases at extreme temperatures. When a gaseous cloud is exposed to extreme negative temperatures, it loses energy and the particles within the cloud slow down. This causes the gas to condense and form solid particles, resulting in the cloud condensing to a solid state. Option (B) is incorrect because extreme negative temperatures would cause the gas particles to lose energy and move closer together, resulting in a decrease in volume rather than an expansion outwardly. Option (C) is incorrect because extreme negative temperatures would not cause the gas to disappear altogether, but rather transform into a different state. Option (D) is incorrect because extreme negative temperatures would cause the gas to condense into a solid rather than become a liquid.

This question requires knowledge about how temperature affects the state of matter. When temperatures are extremely negative, a gaseous cloud can condense to a solid state, forming ice crystals or snow. This process is known as deposition. Option (B) is incorrect because extreme negative temperatures would cause the cloud to contract rather than expand outwardly. Option (C) is also incorrect because extreme temperatures alone would not cause a gaseous cloud to disappear altogether. Option (D) is incorrect because extreme negative temperatures would not cause a gaseous cloud to become a liquid.

This question requires basic knowledge about the behavior of gases at extreme temperatures. When the temperature decreases significantly, gases can undergo a process called condensation, where the gas particles slow down and come closer together, eventually forming a solid. This is why extreme negative temperatures can cause a gaseous cloud to condense and turn into a solid. Option (B) is incorrect because when the particles slow down and come closer together, the cloud would actually contract rather than expand outwardly. Option (C) is not accurate because even at extremely low temperatures, the cloud would still exist in some form, whether it be solid or as individual particles. Option (D) is also incorrect because liquids and gases have different properties, and extreme negative temperatures would not cause a gaseous cloud to become a liquid.

Option (C) may be possible if the cloud loses its source of energy, but it is not specifically related to extreme negative temperatures. Option (D) is incorrect because the process of becoming a liquid involves a gradual decrease in temperature and pressure, not extreme negative temperatures.
